question: What goes into vetting a potential exchange partner?
answer: What goes into vetting a potential exchange partner? There are several basic steps that I've listed below. I will expand on them in later Stories. The quick answer is to get to know your potential exchange partner. And, to do that you need to have multiple interactions (conversations, emails, Skype or Facetime sessions, etc.). As mentioned in earlier posts, SENIORHOMEXCHANGE.COM has InMail that allows you to anonymously communicate with potential exchange partners. It is best to have at least three to five InMail conversations before you decide to Skype, share emails or phone numbers. You want to know as much about them as is reasonable. And, you want to share with your potential exchange partner as much about you as is reasonable. Think quid pro quo. You share and expect to get similar disclosure in return. If you donï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t feel you are getting like-in-kind disclosure from them as you are sharing with them, consider that a red flag. Here are a few topics we will delve into deeper in future Storiis their situation? What about them, in general? 2) What is their motivation for an exchange? 3) How long do they want to exchange? How flexible are they? 4) What are they hoping to experience from the exchange? 5) Are there any limitations related to an exchange (physical, time constraints, special considerations, etc.) 6) What are their interests? 7) What type of personal preferences do they have? The more you learn about them and the more you share about yourself, the more you both become comfortable with each other. And, at the point you both feel comfortable with each other and you feel you are willing to exchange with them is the time to consider taking your conversation off-line by communicating directly via Skype, FaceTime, Facebook, email, phone or what have you.

answer: Why does your potential exchange partner want to exchange? Is this their first exchange or have they exchanged before? If before, how many times? What kind timeframes have they exchanged? Be sure to share with them what you expect them to share with you. Again, the aim is not to interrogate your potential exchange partner. You just want to get to know them and make sure (if you do agree to exchange) it is a good fit for you and them.

question: Are there limitations you need to be aware of if you exchange?
answer: Are there limitations you need to be aware of if you exchange? For example, are there physical limitations that you have or your exchange partner has? Does someone need ADA compliant areas? Are stairs a problem? Is it difficult for someone to navigate a multiple floor home? Is an elevator a requirement or a ramp for wheelchair access a requirement? Are there other limitations or constraints a person needs to be concerned about, like ready access to an airport because they have to take a trip during the exchange? Whatever the situation may be, you will want to understand any and all issues that your prospective exchange partner may have. And, as always, you will want to be transparent about any limitations you may have that they should be aware of.

question: Clearing your Home is about removing clutter, but it is much more than that.
answer: Clearing your Home is about removing clutter, but it is much more than that. Of course, removing clutter is part of the process. We all like a bright open environment. We prefer not to have obstacles where we walk or have to clear things out of the way just to use a space. Your Exchange Partner wonï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t know where you would want items put if they move them. They wonï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½t know how important your items are to you if they place them elsewhere. In the end, you have to make appropriate arrangements so your Exchange Partners are not encumbered with the usual chores associated with maintaining your home while you are away.

question: Clearing your home also means making room for your Exchange Partner.
answer: Clearing your home also means making room for your Exchange Partner. Making space available for them to live during their stay is essential. That includes: Providing at least one clean, unused closet for them to put their clothes, & At least one chest of drawers for them to store other clothing. These are the minimum courtesies you should afford them. They need space to keep their belongings during their stay at your Home just as you will need space at their Home. In addition, it is common to provide a different set of linens for them. That includes sheets, towels and washcloths. It is best and easiest to think what kind of amenities you will need when you are at your Exchange Partnerï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½s Home. They will have the same requirement while staying at your Home. We had no problem with it.important that they let us know they had a special request and that they knew we were willing to accommodate it. Also, it was important to let us know so we could anticipate the shipment. If there is any doubt or concern such amenities will be provided, you should create a list and discuss it with them while Agreeing to the exchange.

question: Documentation is an underappreciated need when exchanging your home.
answer: Documentation is an underappreciated need when it comes to exchanging your home. The good news? Once you've done the work, it only needs to be updated when something has changed. You should Prepare a Binder. You want to document how things operate. For example, we all know how to operate our entertainment centers with our four remotes for the TV, Stereo, Cable Box & DVD, but as any guest will attest, the rest of us have no clue which to turn on first, which remote controls what, etc. It is very helpful if you include pictures of remotes and instructions (if necessary) on which remote operates which device. If you are like us, we have three remotes to operate the HD-TV, the Channel box and the Blueray DVR! How you use them together to play a movie, watch your favorite TV show or sporting event is the trick. Make it easy for your Exchange Partner; document how they are used. You will want to make sure you include important passcodes for WiFi Internet service or the garage keypad, too. We call our book the Home Exchange Binder. You also want to document how to turn the alarm system on or off, how to change the settings on your HVAC system, how to run your appliances (if they are not obvious), where your water shutoff & circuit breaker box are located. If there is an emergency, circuit outage or leak problem, this information is invaluable. You want to think through all the contingencies your Exchange Partner could face while they are in your home. They will need to know such information in the event of an unexpected circumstance. And, when something changes, you want to update your Home Exchange Binder to keep it current. A good example is when you change your cable or Internet service provider. In many cases, the box is different, the remote is different or the WiFi passcode is different. Providing your Exchange Partners with key home operating information is invaluable; for them and for you!

For example, you want to highlight where your water shutoff valve is located in your Home Exchange Binder and label it so your Home Exchange Partner can easily find it. These are the contingencies you need to anticipate. For us, we have multiple water shutoff valves in our basement. Each one has a sign that reads, ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½Water Shutoffï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½. I guess that technically counts as three shutoffs! It is important to clearly label where your circuit breaker box is located and which breakers control what parts of the house. It is also helpful to clearly show where flashlights are located in the event things go dark. There are many things we take for granted in our owhing is located. Not so for your Exchange Partner. Preparing for the unexpected or occasional happenstance makes for a more seamless and enjoyable home exchange; for you and your Exchange Partner.

question: Preparing for your Exchange Partner includes information that is important for them.
How is Planning for a home exchange different than Preparing for it?
answer: How is Planning for a home exchange different than Preparing for it? Planning is about coordinating the exchange. You have already agreed to exchange. You’ve agreed to the parameters for the exchange. Now you want to coordinate with your Exchange Partner . There are logistics that go into the exchange. This is particularly true if you are arranging to exchange vehicles. The first thing that needs to be coordinated is vacating your home at the time your Exchange Partner is intending to arrive (and vice versa). Whether you are driving to the destination or flying, you need to ensure each of you are vacating your home prior to the time the other arrives. If you are exchanging your vehicles and you are arriving via an airport, you both may decide to send a key in advance so you each can drive to the home when you arrive. You may also want to coordinate your flights to arrive at the same airport the same day. We have done this where we sent our car and house key to our exchange partner and they did the same. We both coordinated our flights to arrive at the same airport (we had some options as to which airport so we coordinated the airport and date based on the most beneficial flight costs for us both). When we parked our car, we took a picture of the car, the nearest pole with the row posted on it so our Exchange Partner would be able to easily locate the car. We sent them a text with the picture and a brief description of where it was so they could tell the parking lot bus attendant where to take them. They did the same for us. It was so easy.

question: Planning an exchange also takes into account special needs.
answer: Planning an exchange also takes into account special needs. Some of your Exchange Partners may need to arrange for special circumstances that you will want to accommodate. For instance, they may need special medicine and want to have the medicine delivered before they arrive. You may need to provide special storage (like storing it in a cool environment). They may have a special request where you will want to make sure it is available in your area. And, if not, you will want to make sure they are aware of it in advance. They may be wanting to order something in advance to have it shipped to your home prior to them arriving. This is particularly true when you are arranging an exchange with your Exchange Partner who is coming from outside the country. The lead time for something to be delivered may be longer than their stay and they may want to make sure it arrives either before they exchange or while they are exchanging. We had that happen with one of our Exchange Partners . They were a hobby enthusiast. The item they wanted was quite expensive in Europe. Being many times cheaper in the US, they asked us if they could order it in advance and have the item arrive prior to their visit. We said, “Why not!” They were very appreciative of our flexibility and we didn’t mind at all. Whatever the case, planning is all about coordinating with your Exchange Partner based on the situation.

question: `Planning also means making sure you know what you want to do during your Exchange.
answer: Planning also means making sure you know what you want to do during your Exchange . Where do you want to go? What attractions are you interested in. Will the Exchange serve as a base for local or regional travel? Essentially, you want to ask yourself what you want to accomplish while you are at your Exchange Partner’s Home . For example, your whole motivation for exchanging may be to use your Exchange Partner’s Home as a “base” from which to visit other places. This is especially true for longer exchanges or when you are traveling outside your home country. It is a good practice to share with your Exchange Partner what your motivation is to exchange. They may have particular experience that can be very useful to your stay. The kind of local experience that can prove quite valuable. They may know the best places to go, the best times to go, the best methods of travel to get there and perhaps, based on your interest, be able to recommend other things you had not considered. The more you share with your Exchange Partner what you are planning to do while you are visiting, the more they can help you in ways you haven’t considered.

question: Planning your stay has many obvious benefits.
answer: Planning your stay has many obvious benefits. It also can tell you something about your stay, by comparing what you had planned to do or hoped to do versus what you actually did. To that point, we had an Exchange Partner who planned to visit Montreal & Quebec City during their four weeks stay at our Home . Our Home is near the Canadian border and a reasonable drive to Toronto or Montreal. When we talked to them the week we were coming home, we asked, “How did you like Montreal and Quebec City?” They laughed. They said they were having so much fun doing things in our city that they decided not to make the trip! Imagine that! In the end, they simply liked the things going on around our city and didn’t feel a need to make the drive. Other Exchange Partners may want to use your home as a base to invite family. Do you mind? Maybe, maybe not. But, if you share your plans and they share theirs, you will be aware of their plans (and vice versa), be able to let them know your concerns, if any, and make both of you more comfortable about the plans you have. Planning is all about setting expectations and knowing what you want to accomplish while you are away. The main point is to take advantage of your stay.

question: It is important to know what to bring during your home exchange.
answer: Planning is also important in helping you know what to bring during your home exchange. For example, are you planning to play golf or go fishing? Should you bring your equipment or rent? Does your Exchange Partner have equipment that they would be comfortable you using? Are you planning to shop and bring things home with you? Do you need another piece of luggage that will be empty on your way to the Home Exchange , but will be packed when you return home? Are you an adventure seeker and like to hike, kayak or raft? What equipment can you bring with you? What equipment will you need to rent or buy? Does your Exchange Partner know the best place to rent or buy those items? Are you wanting to shop for certain things that are not available or are much more expensive in your home location? How can your Exchange Partner help in determining where the best places are to visit or shop? These are all important questions to ask yourself as you plan your Home Exchange . The more you can anticipate your needs while you are at your Exchange Partner’s Home , the more you can enjoy the exchange.

question: Planning also involves taking care of your individual needs.
answer: Planning also involves taking care of your individual needs. Individual needs are the things you need due to your physical condition. Such things can include medicines, supplements, clothing, devices or other items that are specific to you and your physical needs. Individual needs can also include preferential items like linens, your favorite sleeping pillow or other comfort items. Whatever they are, you will want to consider what makes you comfortable. Take linens for example. We always provide two new sets of linens for our Home Exchange Partners . However, we have had some Exchange Partners bring their own linens because of allergic reactions to certain kinds of fabrics. They weren’t sure we would have what they needed, so they brought their own. Once you have planned for your individual needs and if you are planning an extended Home Exchange (more than a week), you may want to discuss your requirements with your Exchange Partner to see if they mind you sending some of these items in advance of your exchange or if they already have items that precludes you from having to purchase, bring with you or ship ahead of time. Hey, in the end, whatever makes your Home Exchange comfortable, enjoyable and successful is what matter most!

question: During your stay, there are things you want to do immediately.
answer: During your stay, there are things you want to do immediately. When you first arrive at your Exchange Partner’s Home , you will want to familiarize yourself with your surroundings. You will want to familiarize yourself with; The Home itself ; where things are and how to use them. The Neighborhood ; who are your new neighbors & where to shop for provisions. The Local Area ; where are the shopping centers, Rx centers, etc. The Extended Area ; where are the attractions, things you like to do and places you like to go. Also, there are things that you will want to do During your stay that includes the following. Communicate on a periodic basis with your Exchange Partner . Map Out & Prioritize the things you want to accomplish while you are there. Develop a Things-to-Do List of activities that you want to accomplish during your Exchange . The “To Do” list always includes relaxing! We’ll address these different items in more detail in future Stories .

question: When you arrive familiarize yourself with the operational parts of the Home.
answer: When you first arrive at your Exchange Partner’s Home , familiarize yourself with the operational parts of the Home . Your Exchange Partner should have their Home Exchange Binder laying in a prominent spot (like the kitchen counter or living room table) similarly to what you have done for them. It is also a courtesy if there is a little welcome note on top of the binder. If organized properly, the Home Exchange Binder should have “ How To ” sections on the operational items of the Home . Open the Home Exchange Binder and begin to familiarize yourself with it and the items within the Home . Operational items include how to operate the kitchen appliances, knowing how to use the garage door keypad (if there is one), where the circuit braker box is located & how it is labeled, how to operate the HVAC controls and the entertainment center. Start with the most important items and go from there. Generally, the most important items are the circuit breaker (assuming you’ve arrived during the daytime), the HVAC controls and, in today’s world, the WiFi web key so you have Internet access to your phones, tablets and PC’s. Obviously, next on the short list are the kitchen appliances and the area lighting. Don’t take knowing the area lighting for granted. When it is dark, you will want to know how to turn lights on and off, where they are, particularly if you have steps or stairs to negotiate. Further down the list are things like where the water shutoffs are located, how to operate the garage, are there awning structures or deck umbrellas to operate or how to operate the barbeque grill (if there is one). If there is a pool or spa, how to do you operate those. What are the safety requirements, precautions? In the end, the sooner you familiarize yourself with your Exchange Home , the sooner you will feel comfortable and can begin to settle in like it is Your Home . After all, it is Your Home for the duration of your stay.

question: Get to know the Neighborhood.
answer: Getting to know the Neighborhood is the next step after you’ve familiarize yourself with your Exchange Partner’s Home . And, of course, getting to know your new Neighbors is paramount. These are the people who are looking out for the Homeowner . And, they are looking out for you. That has always been my experience. And, the same thing is happening back at your Home , too. They will want to get to know who you are, where you come from (in more detail than your Exchange Partner shared with them). Neighbors will want to know your interests and your background. They will want to know your career experience and your retirement experience (if you are retired). In short, your new Neighbors will want to learn about you. And, they will want to share things about themselves, too. Before you know it, you’ll be having a glass of wine or a cold beer on the back deck, patio or porch making new friends! As for getting to know the Neighborhood , you will want to know where the vital places are to get all the things you will need. These include the everyday places like gas stations, grocery stores, convenience stores, hardware stores and the like. You will also want to know which gas station has the best prices and which grocery stores have the best prices, produce, fresh food, organics, etc. This is where your new found Neighbors can be very helpful. You will also want to know where Neighborhood facilities are located, when they are open and when they close. Examples include community pools, golf courses, tennis courts, workout facilities and such. In the end, the sooner you familiarize yourself with your new Neighborhood , the more comfortable you will be in your Exchange Partner’s Home .

question: Knowing the Local Area is about exploring.
answer: Knowing the Local Area is about exploring, creating experiences and maintaining safety. Familiarizing yourself with the Local Area surrounding your Exchange Partner’s Home is important. Knowing routes to and from the Home is important. Roads can be blocked and there can be detours due to construction, accidents or other reasons. Knowing alternative routes back to your Exchange Partner’s Home will be helpful, if not expedient. Knowing what a locality has to offer (attractions, entertainment, special interests or places unique to your Exchange Home ) can prove useful in charting your activities during your Exchange . Such local knowledge can enhance your experience during your stay. And, there is the ever-important issue of safety. It’s a sad reality but not every Neighborhood is necessarily safe for outsiders. Knowing areas of a locality to shy away from can be very important, particularly when relying on GPS systems. Sometimes the most direct route is not the best route to take. Deciding to eat at a dining establishment, while highly recommended, that is in a difficult neighborhood may be cause for reconsideration. Knowing the Local Area well enough can enhance your Exchange experience and keep you out of potentially difficult situations.

question: Every Home Exchange you visit has an Extended Area worthy of exploring.
answer: Every Home Exchange you visit has an Extended Area worthy of exploring. Extended Areas can mean many different things depending on the duration associated with your Exchange . If you are only staying for a long weekend or a week, your ability to explore Extended Areas will be somewhat limited. At best, you will only have opportunities to visit extremely unique offerings of that local area. For example, if you are Exchanging with someone from Toronto, Canada and you have not visited Niagara Falls, you might take the time to drive or take the train to Niagara Falls, Canada for the day, even if your Exchange is relatively short. In most cases, for shorter duration Exchanges , you will be looking closer to your Exchange Home . If, on the other hand, you are staying for a couple of weeks or more, planning an overnight stay somewhere during your stay may make for a nice diversion. An example would be Exchanging with someone in Phoenix, AZ. If you have never visited the Grand Canyon and you are as close as Phoenix (a four-hour drive, give or take) you wouldn’t want to pass it up. Whatever your situation, you will always want to look at the Extended Area for opportunities to enhance your Home Exchange experience.

question: Extended Areas can mean many different things.
answer: As mentioned in the previous Story , every Home Exchange you visit has an Extended Area worthy of exploring. Extended Areas can mean many different things depending on the locality of your Home Exchange . If you are visiting a densely populated locality like Baltimore, MD, your ability to explore Extended Areas can extend to other metropolitan areas like Washington DC, Philadelphia and even New York City. Taking advantage of visiting these localities depends on whether you plan to drive or take a train to these areas and, of course, the time you are spending at your Exchange Home . If you are in the western US, there are greater distances between cities. So are other destinations like National Parks. Still, considering visiting such destinations can enhance your Exchange visit. Again, your length of stay and mode of transportation will greatly determine your ability to explore the Extended Areas . Whatever your interest and the locality you are visiting, consider learning more about the Extended Area . If you include them in your plans, your Exchange can be even more rewarding.

question: It is important you Communicate with your Exchange Partners during your Exchange.
answer: It is important you Communicate with your Exchange Partners during your Exchange . Whether you choose to keep in contact via text, a phone call or Skype/Zoom calls depends on several factors. Why and under what circumstances do you need to communicate? If you are just letting them know you’ve arrived and all is well, a text message will suffice. If you are wanting to touch base on an issue that has come up or you are uncertain on how to operate something (that is not included in the Home Exchange Binder ) you may want to text or email to schedule a call, whether by phone, Skype or Zoom. If it is an emergency, you will certainly want to call as soon as possible. If you are unable to connect, you may want to send a text asking your Exchange Partner to return your call at their earliest convenience. Depending upon the emergency, you may want to give them an idea of the issue in the text. If your Exchange is more than a week, you should consider a regularly scheduled meeting each week. Of course, flexibility is important when it comes to adjusting scheduled calls to accommodate both Exchange Partners . Communicate with your Exchange Partner . It will bring comfort and peace during your Exchange stay.

question: Map Out & Prioritize your stay. It helps you take full advantage of your Exchange.
answer: Early in your Home Exchange , Map Out & Prioritize your stay. It helps you take full advantage of your Exchange . You spent time before you arrived at your Exchange Home deciding what you wanted to accomplish during your Exchange . Shortly after you arrive, it is a good idea to review your plans. When you talk with your new Neighbors , they may make you aware of other attractions, places of interest you hadn’t considered or activities you didn’t know about before you arrived. Armed with newer, more complete information, compare your plans. You can make adjustments and changes to your plans. Map Out & Prioritize those plans and know what you want to accomplish During your Home Exchange .

question: Develop a Things-to-Do List shortly after you arrive.
answer: Developing a Things-to-Do List shortly after you arrive sets you up for an enjoyable Home Exchange . Why do I recommend you review your original plans and finalize your Things-to-Do List ? Because you now have all the information necessary to take full advantage of your Home Exchange . We learned the value of creating a Things-to-Do List from one of our Exchange Partners . They were from the west coast of the US and had never visited Montreal or Quebec City. Those cities are four and six hours, respectively, away from our Home . We were Exchanging our Homes for a month. They planned to drive to those cities and stay a few days. As it turned out, they found many more things to do nearer to our Home and cancelled their side trip to Montreal & Quebec City. When we asked why they didn’t make the trek, they said they were having so much fun around our Home locality that they didn’t feel the need to make the trip. The moral of the Story ? It’s important to have a Plan for your Exchange . AND, it’s important to review the Plan During your visit to fully enjoy your Exchange experience. All those we’ve Exchanged with whole heartedly agree!

question: After you have arrived back home from your Exchange, there are some things you should do.
answer: After you have arrived back home from your Exchange , there are some things you should do. You should confirm with your Exchange Partner that you have arrived safely back Home . You should reiterate with your Exchange Partner your willingness to discuss anything that they find related to your visit. If your find issues related to your Exchange Partner’s visit, you should convey those as soon as possible after you arrive back Home . You should log into SENIORHOMEXCHANGE.COM and review your Exchange Partner while your experience is fresh in your mind. We will be covering these items in more detail in subsequent Stories .

question: Let your Exchange Partner know you arrived safely at your Home.
answer: After your Exchange , you should let your Exchange Partner know you arrived safely at your Home . It is a common courtesy and a nice way to bring closure to your Exchange experience. You can communicate via text or make a quick phone call. During the contact, you should reiterate your openness to be contacted in the future especially if your Exchange Partner finds something wrong with the Home since your stay. Remaining open and being available is another courtesy you can afford your Exchange Partner . We have remained in contact with many of our Exchange Partners over the years as we follow the path of their lives, and they follow ours.

question: Resolving Issues After an Exchange
answer: Once both Exchange Partners have arrived home, there may be issues that need to be resolved. These can fall into several categories. Simple Questions – These do not impact either partner. Minor or Major Issues – These directly involve the Exchange Partners. If your Exchange Partner has a simple question, obviously you want to provide any information you can for them. If it is a matter of a minor or major issue, it is best to make yourself available in a direct way via phone conversation or video conference to discuss the issue in detail. Having that personal contact can me instrumental to clear communication and help avoid misunderstandings. Both Exchange Partners should be open to resolving the issue in the most equitable way possible given the circumstance. There are two things at work here. We should always want to practice the “Golden Rule”, asking how we would want the situation resolved if the roles were reversed. You and your Exchange Partner can (and should) Rate each other After the Exchange . Any unsatisfactorily resolved issues can be raise in the review. Again, clarity and objectiveness should dictate your review of the situation. In general, you should always report to your Exchange Partner any issues that arise During your Exchange and resolve them at that time. It will leave you both with the best possible Exchange experience.

question: Rating your Exchange Partner & your Exchange experience.
answer: After you have returned from your Exchange Partner’s home, you should make sure there are no unresolved issues between you. It is best to have one last communication between both Exchange Partners to bring closure to your Exchange experience. At that point, you are in a position to Rate your Exchange Partner . You Rate your Exchange Partner by going to Seniorhomexchange.com , logging in and going to the Public Page of your Exchange Partner . You can Rate them on a scale of 1 to 5 for the following elements. Accuracy Location Communication Flexibility Cleanliness Value You can add a comment to add detail to the ratings you give your Exchange Partner . When you submit your Rating of your Exchange Partner , you are then able to see how your Exchange Partner has Rated you. Note, if you have not yet Rated your Exchange Partner , you will not be able to see how you were Rated by your Exchange Partner until you have Rated them.

question: Getting the most from your Membership.
answer: Seniorhomexchange.com allows you to add details to your Home Exchange Profile  and Property Attributes . Taking the time to populate these fields will make you and your property stand out to other Members . Some of these attributes are used as key search elements when a Member wants to narrow their search for compatible Exchange Partners . In addition, there are description fields where you can describe who you are and what types of Exchanges you are interested in (in the case of the Personal Profile ). There is a similar description field for you Property Profile which allows you to describe important elements of your Property and the local attractions a prospective Exchange Partner would have an interested visiting. It is no surprise, Members who have more fully completed their Personal and Property profiles have more engagement with other Members wishing to Exchange .

question: Completing your Personal and Property Profiles.
answer: Getting to the point of finding a good Exchange opportunity starts with being as transparent as possible. Having a complete Profile is important in attracting Exchange Partners. The more you share about yourself, your Home and your interest, the more likely you are to attract interest from other Members . The Vetting process, when properly done will make you and your Exchange Partners comfortable with Exchanging your Homes . The attributes available to you in your Personal and Property profiles are designed to help other members narrow their search for the Exchange they seek. By filling out as many applicable details about yourself and your Home , other Exchange Members are able to quickly and easily differentiate and find you. Being able to stand out for other Exchange Members is the key to increased opportunities for Home Exchanges .

question: Using Personal Profile Attributes.
answer: Certain elements of your Personal Profile are available to other Members when they Explore (search) Member Properties . The Personal Profile elements visible on your Public Profile are as follows. Profile Image – Your Profile Image Public Name – Usually your first name and the first name of your significant other. About Us – a description of yourself and your interests. Member Affiliations – These are affiliations you may have like military, law enforcement or education professions. Personal information like your last name nad email address a not shared on your Public Profile . Members initial communication with you will always be via the Seniorhomexchange.com In-Mail .

question: Using Property Profile Attributes blog by Senior Home Exchange
answer: When you first create (list) your first Property (you can create up to two Property Profiles ) you should complete as many attributes as applicable. The following Property Attributes are shown on your Public Profile . Uploaded Property Images – The images you have uploaded. Property Location Details – Country, Region, State/Province & Metro Area (if applicable). Home Attribute Details – These include Home type, # of Floors, # of Bedrooms & # of Bathrooms Property Description – The Description you provided for your Property . Special Considerations – Pets Allowed or Smoking Allowed. Home Amenities – Transportation, Entertainment, Living & Miscellaneous. Completing these details make it easier for other Members to Explore (search) and find your Property listing. For more details and information check our website's other blogs. Seniorhomexchange.com Home Exchange are easier than expected, arrange your next exchange through our website.

question: Using Member Personal Attributes
answer: Seniorhomexchange.com provides Members the ability to designate Personal Attributes . These Personal Attributes are used as Advanced Search criteria when other Members use the Explore Places to Go search engine. The main Personal Attributes include the following. Personal Affiliations – These are career associations. Member Preferences – These are lifestyle items. Exchange Preferences – These are the types of exchange durations you prefer. Affiliations and Preferences make easier for likeminded Exchange Partners to find you and you to find them! Well discuss how these can be important in future Bob’s Blogs .

question: Why use Personal Affiliations
answer: Our studies show that people are more comfortable Exchanging their Home with people who are similarly aligned. That can mean they have similar life experiences, are of the similar background or are of similar generational age. That is precisely why SeniorHomeXchange.com focuses on those who are 50+. We’ve found it’s a generational thing! Yet, within this broad generational age group, there are subgroups that prefer to Exchange with others of the same subgroup. One such subgroup is work Affiliation . Here are the Affiliations you’ve asked us to create as subgroups. Military – Active or Retired Law Enforcement – Active or Retired Educator – Active or Retired If you have an Affiliation with either of these subgroups, you will enhance your ability for an Exchange with those who prefer to exchange with the same subgroup. In all circumstances, SeniorHomeXchange.com exists for you to find likeminded Exchange Partners . We try to make it easy for other Members to find you and for you to find them!

question: Why use Member Preferences
answer: Member Preferences are lifestyle items. These are items that we prefer or do not prefer. These Preferences allow Exchange Partners to identify those Members with similar  Member Preferences . The more you have in common with other members, the more likely you will agree to exchange your home. Here are the Personal Preferences you’ve asked us to highlight. Birder Fisherman Golfer Hiker Non-Smoker Pet Owner Skier Wine Enthusiast If you have an affinity with either of these subgroups, you are more likely to decide to  Exchange  your home with those who are from the same subgroup. In all circumstances, SeniorHomeXchange.com exists for you to find likeminded Exchange Partners . We try to make it easy for other Members to find you and for you to find them!

question: Why use Exchange Preferences
answer: Exchange Preferences are the length of Exchange you are interested in. It is best to select all that apply. Other Exchange Partners are looking to Exchange for specific durations, but their preference for an exchange can vary depending upon the time of year, the season, etc. Here are the Exchange Preferences you’ve asked us to highlight. Long Weekend Five to Ten Days Several Weeks Month or More Again, if you think you will be open to any Exchange duration, you will enhance your ability for an Exchange if you select all the Exchange Preference time ranges. In all circumstances, SeniorHomeXchange.com exists for you to find likeminded Exchange Partners . We try to make it easy for other Members to find you and for you to find them!

question: How Important are Property Attributes?
answer: Property attributes matter, but not for the reason you may think. Accurately depicting your property is very important for you and the satisfaction of your exchange partner. What is interesting though, for most members, the equality of an exchange (in terms of the property) is less important than other factors. We’ve exchange with other members where their home was much nicer than ours. And, we’ve had other exchanges where the reverse was true. Why is the disparity of a property not so important in an exchange? Because an exchange is temporary in nature and, therefore, other factors are more important, like locality or circumstance. For example, if you are exchanging because you are visiting family, your most important factor is going to a place that is near them. Or you may be going to an out-of-town wedding. In either case, the location matters far more than whether the home you are staying at is exactly as nice as your home. Having said that, Property Attributes are important to let other members know what to expect if they exchange with you.

question: Why use Property Attributes?
answer: Property Attributes allow other members know details about your property. Property Attributes include the following. Home Type Number of Floors Number of Bedrooms Number of Bathrooms Transportation issues Entertainment Living Amenities Miscellaneous Special Considerations Making selections as they apply to your home and your situation is very helpful to other members searching for potential exchange partners. For example, if another member has physical restrictions, exchanging with a member who has a multi-floor dwelling may not be suitable for them. That member may want to limit their searches to members who have a single floor home arrangement (or a condo with elevator access). The more details you can provide about your home, the greater the potential for finding members who can or will want to exchange with you.

question: Why provide details about your property?
answer: Details about your property can be broken into several categories. Details about your home. Details related to transportation. Home amenities. Special Considerations We have created these categories to help you inform other members about your property. Each of these categories helps you determine your interest in another member’s property. And, they help another member determine their interest in your property. Home exchanging involves finding the “right” situations. That includes timing (when to go and for how long), where to go and does a property suit your situation. It is this latter point that we are focused on here.

question: Why specifics about your home are important?
answer: Details about your home relate to the physical living space. This matters for members who may have limitations or specific needs. For example, if a potential exchange partner has some physical limitation that precludes them from walking up and down steps, they will want to look for other member properties that are on a single floor (either a single floor home or a condo with elevator access). These categories are physical in nature. Home Type Number of Floors Number of Bedrooms Number of Bathrooms Number of bedrooms may be important if your exchange partner is wanting to invite family members to visit them during their exchange. That has happened in our case and, of course, you will want to declare your intention and clear it with your exchange partner to make sure they are ok with it.

question: People have exchanged their automobiles!
answer: Why are details pertaining to transportation important? It matters to your exchange partner. Here are the elements you can select. Free Parking Is there are garage? Is a golf cart available? Are you open to a vehicle exchange. Imagine, going someplace for a month, exchanging your home and your automobile. Now that is a low-cost getaway! No rental car or hotel cost.   Of course, you have to be comfortable with your exchange partner, but it is something we’ve done. It was fantastic! People also want to know what issue they have with parking while at their exchange partner's place. Is there designated parking (like in a condo complex)? Does your vehicle need to be registered in order to get into a gated community? These are the kind of considerations you and your exchange partner need to be aware of.
